title: Lol @Tahm Kench nerfs
body: People complaining about his stupid amount of damage and inability to die....you nerf his move speed when he devours an ally. #Ritologic

replies.body:
People tend to complain about the most distinctive things a champion does. Nerfing based off what people complain about can eventually end up homogenizing characters a lot, with everyone having a similar feeling kit and unique effects reduced from character defining to secondary sources of novelty. To combat that we instead map out what we think are appropriate strengths and weaknesses for each champion and try and nerf/buff to preserve (or accentuate) those. In this case nerfing the MS with an ally devoured was we felt the best way to do that for Tahm in 5.24. 

That's not to say player frustration isn't a really useful thing to monitor and understand, it's really valuable for helping to build or modify those intended strengths/weaknesses in the first place. Being really informed of player feedback, frustations, needs, wants etc's something we believe's really important. That's not the same though as believing that whatever a lot of people are saying is necessarily the right thing to do though.
When designing champion kits, do you guys foresee results reactions like the these boards have?

Some of the time, yes. We expected Tahm Kench's ally devour to create quite a bit of frustration when it saved allies for example. We felt during his development (and still do now too) though that that was an acceptable cost given the positive moments and gameplay Devour creates.

Just for an exemple, on a scale of frustration list below, where do you place tham kench devour?

1) WW ult
2) blitz grab
3) pre nerf kalista mobility
4) zed safety
5) katarina smartcast
6) old skarner permaslow
7) 3 stack free damage mechanics
8) annie insta aoe stun
9) rengar insta kill
10) yasuo windwall

And here you have hit upon Tahms identity, he eats his allies and saves them. You nerfed that instead of the bits of his kit that were not disctinctive, namely his ability to do damage. Everyone can do damage, his utility is unique and what makes tahm tahm.

But if they nerfed his damage, Tahm might have trouble in Solo lane, and all we hear about is how great a SUPPORT he is, so let's try to tone down his SUPPORTing, despite the fact that what everyone COMPLAINS about is his SOLOing.

Damage doesn't make Tahm unique, if you want damage play Darius, Riven, Rumble, or Garen. Maokai and Naut are still viable solo laners with utility instead of high damage. High damage is not necessary for solo lane viability. 

Just because people complain about one thing doesn't mean they are wrong for doing so. It doesn't make them right but you can't discount it just because it is the popular complaint. They certainly shouldn't cater to every popular idea, but in this instance they dismissed the nature of the complaints and purposefully went in the opposite direction of the popular opinion. This change shows a sort of reverse bandwagon fallacy where because the popular opinion was one way, they went the other. 

Also the caps isn't helping you make an argument any more. I can read what role you're referring to without you having to caps them.

Which is why reasonable players asked you to nerf his movement speed. Tahm Kench has 335 MS when he really should have 325 MS given the extreme power of his Devour (Ally or Enemy alike). It should be a struggle for him to enter melee range precisely to offset the tremendous damage and utility his skills have.

I don't think anyone was clamoring for his MS when running away with a devoured ally to be decreased.
OP got rekt

well, that doesnÂ´t excuse ignoring all arguments that go along with the complains and frustration at most times (@retcon, Yasuo, Crit, Marksmen dominace, ...)

I don't want to seem like a contrarian, but I think Riot tend to over-emphasise players complaints about the unique features of a champion's kit and not get to the actual core of the complaints. 

It's well known that Riot tries to create champions with distinct strengths and weaknesses, as well as champions with unique mechanics. Usually these go hand in hand, the distinct strengths a champion possesses will usually be attached to and based on that champions unique mechanics (as these tend to be what Riot balances around - typically these abilities are tuned very highly to make them impactful and rewarding).  I feel like there are two distinct problems here:
1 - players complain about the distinct skills not because they are unique and they want champions homogenising, but because these skills are the most likely to be over-tuned. Relatedly, I feel like Riot's balance is philosophy is leaning towards ever more exaggerated high points / strengths - new champions and remakes tend to push things to the extreme in terms of what is acceptable balance wise, so many end up getting nerfed. Riot have talked about the arms race in top lane before but I feel like it's going on pretty much all the time, which is why we get new champions who come out and just dominate, then have to be nerfed significantly (Azir, Tahm, Kalista and Gnar being recent examples).
2 - Riot are MUCH better at scoring distinct strengths than weaknesses or even distinct weaknesses. Take the juggernauts - they came out and most of them had to be nerfed because they had no real weakness, Azir was similar, low HP didn't really meaningfully stop him doing what he was capable of doing. While champions don't feel as overloaded as they did in the past - Irelia - instead they feel like their strengths overall cover their weaknesses too well, so while play is more fun as those champions counterplay is flatter (Fiora). So when you can't substantially counter those champions and then they hit you with their strength points you get frustrated. That's my take on things anyway.

When you (Riot) nerf things like you did with Tahm, you end up completely destroying the champion (though in the case of Tahm, I'm fine with it) because you're going to end up nerfing his damage and durability anyway without reverting what you already did. Right now, the movement bonus he got meant nothing. Removing it did not reduce his power at all. When he inevitably receives changes to not have 200% health or a passive 44% damage reduction, that movement speed would have meant something, and he's not going to have it.

Isn't Tahm's purpose to save allies though? I feel that you end up homogenizing him more by hitting his strength over his stats (ult passive). I still agree with the solution, but the way you came to this (or explained it) seems off.
